title: The Surprising Reason Leaving the Office Earlier Is Fine, But Showing Up Late Is Not
description: Corporate America is trying to drag the workplace back towards pre-pandemic norms. Some things have changed for good.
content:
Remember the dread you used to feel when you were fractionally late for school, and you had to race to get to class on time or face trouble from your teacher?Now, sitting at your office desk, glancing over at the corner office, that uneasy sensation of being pressured to be on time never went away, did it? That feeling is supported by a recent study that shows that showing up late to work is still highly frowned on, the Wall Street Journal reports.

But that same study also found that in our post-pandemic working world, where hybrid arrangements still persist, it’s getting easier to leave the office a little earlier, on occasion. This is not a sign that corporate America working norms have softened, however. And if you look under the surface of the trend, it’s not as much an indicator of pro-mental health attitudes as it seems to be. The study was carried out by Chicago-headquartered commercial real estate giant JLL, which used anonymized cellphone data to determine when people arrived and left an office space. The study only covered its own buildings, since this is where it could access this data, but as the Journal notes, “the firm’s scale and range of tenants make the findings a decent proxy for broader trends.” The data show some geographic variations. In New York, JLL workers were heading home an average 13 minutes a day earlier than they left the office in 2019—nearly a quarter of an hour, or (if you’re getting statistical about it), 1/32 of a full work day. But in Dallas, Texas, workers are leaving a full 18 minutes later than in 2019. And in San Francisco, until recently a bellwether for progressive workplace attitudes? A decent 26 minutes later. Nearly half an hour! What luxury!

Before you think people are shirking their duties, it’s not the case. Even if companies are more flexible about letting employees clock off a little early to deal with their kids’ extracurricular activities, or hit a restaurant with friends or tackle personal issues, there’s still an expectation that workers will log on a little later on in the evening and check what’s happened so that they’re up to speed for the next morning. There’s a little grain of guilt glistening inside that last paragraph. And there are others, too. One worker the Journal spoke to started Zooming colleagues in Europe as soon as her kids were on the school bus, just before 7 a.m., but if the meetings delayed her physical arrival in the office until 10 o’clock, she felt bad as she walked in. “I still have this sense like it’s weird that I’m getting in now because the day’s already up and running,” she said. All of this speaks to an issue that pervades U.S. workspaces, the Journal says: Productivity theater.

Think of trends like “coffee badging,” where staff arrive in the morning, say hi to a few people, grab a cuppa joe, then disappear. Or the Gen-Z trend of “task masking,” making conspicuous, deliberate attempts to look busy in the office even if you’re not—a trend fueled by worries over being replaced by an AI. And then there’s “clock botching,” which is the most damaging form of productivity theater. Here workers string out simple tasks for multiple hours not because they’re skipping work, but because they’re masking the fact they’re right on the edge of catastrophic emotional burnout. Even the American trend of shunning vacation time has been in the headlines recently, with many workers refusing to use their allotted days (even if they have them in the first place) on the grounds they feel guilty for letting people down. Why should you care about this, though?

Because it’s possible that your workers have different ideas about the importance of how much time is time spent actually working while at work than you do, as a leader. It’s also very easy for “unofficial” habits to fall into place — be they “show up early to impress the boss” or “it’s ok if you scoot off five minutes early to catch the bus.” If you have strong feelings about how and when your workers actually work, then communicating this openly and honestly is probably a good idea. It shows workers where you stand, and it may even relieve some of the mental stresses that being late or needing to leave early can cause your staff. Because real life is real life, no matter how many tasks are on the office to-do list. And remember: Gen-Z is shunning the 9-to-5 grind for a reason, and we may have lots to learn from them.
summary: A study by Chicago-based commercial real estate giant JLL has found that leaving the office earlier to work is still highly frowned on. However, this is not a sign that corporate America working norms have softened. The study used anonymized cellphone data to determine when people arrived and left an office space. In New York, workers were heading home an average 13 minutes a day earlier than they left the office in 2019, or nearly a quarter of an hour, or 1/32 of a full work day, compared to 18 minutes later in Dallas, Texas. In San Francisco, the firm's scale and range of tenants make these findings a proxy for broader trends. The research also highlights the issue of productivity theater, where employees often skip work multiple times due to exhaustion or stress.
shortSummary: Despite our workplace norms, late work late is still a taboo, driven by pressure to be on time, though this trend may actually enhance productivity and mental health.
argos_summary: A JLL study using anonymized cellphone data shows that while late arrivals to work remain frowned upon, employees are increasingly leaving offices earlier in a post‑pandemic hybrid environment, with significant geographic variation—New York workers leave 13 minutes early, Dallas 18 minutes late, and San Francisco 26 minutes late. The trend is not a sign of relaxed norms but reflects flexible arrangements that still expect employees to stay late to catch up, creating a culture of "productivity theater" such as coffee badging and task masking. The article highlights how these unofficial habits can mask burnout and guilt over taking vacation, urging leaders to communicate expectations openly to reduce mental stress and align workplace practices with evolving employee attitudes.
